metadata.synopsis: Jaheira's default dialogue. Topics range from her past life to her current goals as they develop. Unless otherwise stated, her tone is confident and to the point. She's a seasoned adventurer with a sardonic sense of humour - and a little less cynical than she might present herself to be.

61.speaker: Jaheira
61.text: If you have questions, ask. Just don't expect my answers to rhyme.
61.context: NodeContext: Relenting to answer questions, but not overly begrudging. We've earned this

88.speaker: Jaheira
88.text: If you have questions, ask. Just don't expect my answers to rhyme.
88.context: NodeContext: Relenting to answer questions, but not overly begrudging. We've earned this

96.speaker: Jaheira
96.text: If you have questions, ask. Just don't expect my answers to rhyme.
96.context: NodeContext: Relenting to answer questions, but not overly begrudging. We've earned this

113.speaker: Player
113.text: Is it true that you've fought the Dead Three before?
113.context: NodeContext: Style of "hate to break it to you, kid"

19.speaker: Jaheira
19.text: It was Bhaal alone we faced in our time - and bad as that was, he had no elder brain for a lapdog then.
19.context: NodeContext: Style of "hate to break it to you, kid"

50.speaker: Jaheira
50.text: Help won't come from the history books, or from any old tales I can spin you. This is your story to write.
50.context: NodeContext: Style of "hate to break it to you, kid"

102.speaker: Jaheira
102.text: There: have I fulfilled my role as your wise and wizened elder?
102.context: NodeContext: A little wry - aware she was waxing poetic about the past

51.speaker: Player
51.text: Please. You're only one of those things.
51.context: NodeContext: Jaheira has said she "wise and wizened", player has said she's only one of those things.

133.speaker: Jaheira
133.text: Don't tell me which. Against all life experience, I will choose to assume the best.
133.context: NodeContext: Jaheira has said she "wise and wizened", player has said she's only one of those things.

63.speaker: Player
63.text: I'm not certain you are older than me.

16.speaker: Jaheira
16.text: Oh. Good. Then I am under no obligation to be wise.

108.speaker: Player
108.text: You're not that old - are you?
108.context: NodeContext: Obfuscating her age as if coy - but bluntly confirming it in the next line.

22.speaker: Jaheira
22.text: I've passed enough years that counting them is a waste of what remains.
22.context: NodeContext: Obfuscating her age as if coy - but bluntly confirming it in the next line.

134.speaker: Jaheira
134.text: Which is to say - yes. I am that old.
134.context: NodeContext: Not overly harsh, but a little sardonic:

109.speaker: Player
109.text: You seem reluctant to discuss the past.
109.context: NodeContext: Gently fobbing us off with a joke - she'll get into her past with us another time

10.speaker: Jaheira
10.text: What need, when it seems so intent on repeating itself?
10.context: NodeContext: Gently fobbing us off with a joke - she'll get into her past with us another time

121.speaker: Jaheira
121.text: But stay this apocalypse and I'll let you read my journals. Promise.

118.speaker: Player
118.text: You mentioned you know something of illithids.
118.context: NodeContext: Bad taste in her mouth

117.speaker: Jaheira
117.text: More than I would like. In my youth, I was a brief - and very much unwilling - member of a colony's hivemind.
117.context: NodeContext: Bad taste in her mouth

12.speaker: Jaheira
12.text: I felt the way they think. Saw the world as they do. Foul, unnatural creatures, who find the foulness in us and twist it to their will.
12.context: NodeContext: Recalling her time as an illithid thrall with utter distaste - to be robbed of free will is disgusting

120.speaker: Jaheira
120.text: But then - who am I speaking to? You have far more experience than I.

72.speaker: Player
72.text: Who are you speaking to? Maybe I'm the parasite, puppeting this body.

21.speaker: Jaheira
21.text: Then greetings, saer tadpole. I was wondering where all the questions suddenly sprang from.

112.speaker: Player
112.text: It's different this time. The elder brain is a slave itself.
112.context: NodeContext: All joking aside, a gentle warning

136.speaker: Jaheira
136.text: Do not be moved to pity. It is a predator, pinned in a trap.
136.context: NodeContext: All joking aside, a gentle warning

23.speaker: Jaheira
23.text: And if it wriggles free, you'll find it still has teeth.

67.speaker: Player
67.text: My mind is still my own. I plan to keep it that way.

36.speaker: Jaheira
36.text: I believe you. You remind me of another I knew, marked by forces beyond their control.

1.speaker: Jaheira
1.text: The gods can grant power or strip it away - but so long as your will remains, you have the only weapon you need.

46.speaker: Player
46.text: You travelled with a child of Bhaal in times past, did you not?
46.context: NodeContext: Shrugging - a little guarded about getting into stories of the old days

42.speaker: Jaheira
42.text: I did. Though I don't often speak of it - so many seem to think they know the whole story already, I find it a pity to correct them.
42.context: NodeContext: Shrugging - a little guarded about getting into stories of the old days

135.speaker: Jaheira
135.text: We can speak of old battles later - our plate is piled high with catastrophes enough for the present, hm?
135.context: NodeContext: Trying to steer our attention back to our own fight - out of pragmatism, but also because she doesn't want to discuss the topic of Bhaal with us.

94.speaker: Player
94.text: I need to know more about the Bhaalspawn. About myself.
94.context: NodeContext: Very nostalgic, former Jaheira romancers should feel a little heartbroken, but she shouldn't entirely imply it was her.

13.speaker: Jaheira
13.text: You've already bested your father. I would advise against fighting the battle over again in your mind.
13.context: NodeContext: Very nostalgic, former Jaheira romancers should feel a little heartbroken, but she shouldn't entirely imply it was her.

6.speaker: Jaheira
6.text: But if you have questions - you've earned whatever answers I can give.
6.context: NodeContext: Very nostalgic, former Jaheira romancers should feel a little heartbroken, but she shouldn't entirely imply it was her.

130.speaker: Player
130.text: Was your camp bothered time and time again by a grotesque Butler?
130.context: NodeContext: Very nostalgic, former Jaheira romancers should feel a little heartbroken, but she shouldn't entirely imply it was her.

131.speaker: Jaheira
131.text: Bhaal had his minions, certainly. But none that watched over their wards so diligently.

87.speaker: Jaheira
87.text: I wonder if past experience has taught the great god to fear - that another of his children might turn against him.

29.speaker: Player
29.text: Did your friend ever tell you of the dreams Bhaal sent them?
29.context: NodeContext: Very nostalgic, former Jaheira romancers should feel a little heartbroken, but she shouldn't entirely imply it was her.

52.speaker: Jaheira
52.text: Yes. Your rancid father will try to twist your thoughts, as he did with all his children.

116.speaker: Jaheira
116.text: The harder you resist, the darker your dreams become. Our camp was often roused by screams in the night, back then.

25.speaker: Jaheira
25.text: We learned to take them as a marker of pride. Even gods can be resisted.

129.speaker: Player
129.text: Did the Bhaalspawn have children? Did they inherit his taint?
129.context: NodeContext: Very nostalgic, former Jaheira romancers should feel a little heartbroken, but she shouldn't entirely imply it was her.

84.speaker: Jaheira
84.text: A Bhaalspawn can sire children, certainly. We have Sarevok and Orin as proof of that. Whether they should...
84.context: NodeContext: Very nostalgic, former Jaheira romancers should feel a little heartbroken, but she shouldn't entirely imply it was her.

85.speaker: Jaheira
85.text: There are things in our nature we might unwittingly pass on, yes. But I do not believe them stronger than the things we choose to pass on.
85.context: NodeContext: Very nostalgic, former Jaheira romancers should feel a little heartbroken, but she shouldn't entirely imply it was her.

74.speaker: Jaheira
74.text: If you are asking whether love and joy are beyond you, just because of the taint in your blood...
74.context: NodeContext: Very nostalgic, former Jaheira romancers should feel a little heartbroken, but she shouldn't entirely imply it was her.

31.speaker: Jaheira
31.text: No. They most certainly are not.
31.context: NodeContext: Very nostalgic, former Jaheira romancers should feel a little heartbroken, but she shouldn't entirely imply it was her.

95.speaker: Jaheira
95.text: A Bhaalspawn can sire children, certainly. Whether they should...

132.speaker: Player
132.text: I think you've told me enough.

69.speaker: Jaheira
69.text: I am no expert on the matter, despite all my experience. But - if anything I know can help you to resist your father... only ask it.
69.context: NodeContext: Grim resolve. She'll do everything she can to help us, even if she isn't sure what exactly that is

76.speaker: Player
76.text: You've never known a Bhaalspawn to go mad, have you?

0.speaker: Jaheira
0.text: Not... mad, no. Take Sarevok, for example. For as much carnage as he caused, there was always a cold calculation to it.

27.speaker: Jaheira
27.text: He craved power, and his bloodline was just another path to achieve it. I saw that same bloodline turned to better ends than Bhaal ever intended for it.

9.speaker: Jaheira
9.text: It was Bhaalspawn who threatened the Coast, and Bhaalspawn who saved it. It is possible to go on to live a life outside your father's shadow.

97.speaker: Player
97.text: Did your friend live happily, once Bhaal was dealt with?

107.speaker: Jaheira
107.text: Ha! Bhaal was but the beginning. Be warned - a godspawn draws trouble like iron to lodestone.

119.speaker: Jaheira
119.text: There will be crusaders who wish to rid the world of your taint, or jealous minds who believe themselves more deserving of the power in your blood.

127.speaker: Jaheira
127.text: I'm sure Gale has heard the cautionary tale of the mad mage Jon Irenicus.

110.speaker: Gale
110.text: Naturally. Irenicus, or 'The Exile', sought to extract divinity from Bhaalspawn blood. Needless to say, he failed in quite catastrophic fashion - hence the cautionary part of the tale.

5.speaker: Jaheira
5.text: But happiness is not beyond a Bhaalspawn. It simply comes at a higher cost - constant vigilance.

125.speaker: Jaheira
125.text: I will not mince words: if what you told me is true, you are already further under Bhaal's power than my old friend ever was.

98.speaker: Jaheira
98.text: But so long as you fear that power, there is hope. Fear means you are not fully mad - not yet.

14.speaker: Player
14.text: You were telling me about the Harpers.
14.context: NodeContext: Not fobbing us off, just amused - those are her memories, and she won't be drawn into waxing poetic (Right now). Think old man Steve Rogers when asked about Peggy at the end of Avengers: Endgame.

71.speaker: Player
71.text: Want to tell me more about this someone you loved?
71.context: NodeContext: Not fobbing us off, just amused - those are her memories, and she won't be drawn into waxing poetic (Right now). Think old man Steve Rogers when asked about Peggy at the end of Avengers: Endgame.

101.speaker: Jaheira
101.context: NodeContext: Not fobbing us off, just amused - those are her memories, and she won't be drawn into waxing poetic (Right now). Think old man Steve Rogers when asked about Peggy at the end of Avengers: Endgame.

70.speaker: Player
70.text: Surely people understand that the Harpers are working for the greater good.
70.context: NodeContext: Snort, absolutely not getting into the philosophical discussion - she just does the job

55.speaker: Jaheira
55.text: Hah! No, no thank you - let the wiser members of my order wrinkle their brows over that particular phrase.
55.context: NodeContext: Snort, absolutely not getting into the philosophical discussion - she just does the job

38.speaker: Jaheira
38.text: In all my years fighting for the Harpers, I am still never certain what 'the greater good' means. I've learned to be content with: 'well, that was not so bad as it might have been'.

2.speaker: Player
2.text: How did you end up joining?
2.context: NodeContext: Shrug. She has a sob story like everyone, but isn't interested in indulging it

28.speaker: Jaheira
28.text: I will not bore you with a long tale. The short: I was born to a high family in Tethyr. I remember little, except that when my family fell, they fell far. And fast.
28.context: NodeContext: Shrug. She has a sob story like everyone, but isn't interested in indulging it

18.speaker: Jaheira
18.text: I learned young what fear and hunger make desperate people do. I learned to do some of it myself, even, until a roving circle of hedge-druids found me.
18.context: NodeContext: Remembering bad years of her youth, but evenly, not great pathos or lingering trauma. She wound up luckier than most in her view.

15.speaker: Jaheira
15.text: They raised me in the wild. But when it became clear I was perhaps not suited to a life of idle reflection, I was sent to the Harpers. To do.
15.context: NodeContext: Dry, amused at herself - she loves being a druid and living in nature, but always wanted to be active

75.speaker: Jaheira
75.text: They showed me how to fight with sword as well as spell, and gave me ample causes to wield them for. If I was not always the truest believer in every cause, well...
75.context: NodeContext: Fond, remembering her husband Khalid (a topic she will not be drawn on here)

59.speaker: Jaheira
59.text: I fell in love with someone who was. And that is almost the same thing.
59.context: NodeContext: Fond, remembering her husband Khalid (a topic she will not be drawn on here)

24.speaker: Player
24.text: It sounds like you and the Harpers have a complicated history.
24.context: NodeContext: Affirming, amused at her own hot-headedness in youth. She lost faith with the Harpers more than once, but always comes back.

126.speaker: Jaheira
126.text: Oh, you might say that. I left their service and swore never to return. Multiple times, if I recall.
126.context: NodeContext: Affirming, amused at her own hot-headedness in youth. She lost faith with the Harpers more than once, but always comes back.

33.speaker: Jaheira
33.text: It is easy to get tired of the intrigue. The high causes shrouded in secrecy. I thought I might find another way to be of use to the world.

68.speaker: Jaheira
68.text: And for a time, I did. But my comrades would use a rather irritating phrase: 'A Harper never leaves the chorus - she simply goes to spread the song.'

99.speaker: Jaheira
99.text: Meaning that whatever cause I turned my hand to, there I would find them. Harpers, stuffed with their own virtue - but always there. Always trying to help.

79.speaker: Jaheira
79.text: So I returned to the fold. Returned to the city. Eventually, they hung a title around my neck: 'High Harper'. And I still do not know how to play one.
79.context: NodeContext: Helpless shrug at her now grand title. She doesn't know how she wound up here, either.

128.speaker: Jaheira
128.text: If I wanted to spare Geraldus the same headaches, well... you know now why I needed him to be sure this is the life he wants.
128.context: NodeContext: Closing off the topic, catching herself talking a lot and impatient to get going again (but not harshly so)

45.speaker: Jaheira
45.text: If I tried to spare Geraldus the same headaches, well - now you know why. And if he is half the Harper I suspect, it won't make a damned bit of difference.
45.context: NodeContext: Closing off the topic, catching herself talking a lot and impatient to get going again (but not harshly so)

89.speaker: Jaheira
89.text: But you're staring - which means the tadpole has finally eaten your brain, or I have been talking too much. Either way, time to move - no?
89.context: NodeContext: Closing off the topic, catching herself talking a lot and impatient to get going again (but not harshly so)

81.speaker: Player
81.text: What can you tell me about the Harpers?
81.context: NodeContext: A little mock-wary about getting into the topic - people have a lot of opinions about the Harpers - but relenting, dryly amused

93.speaker: Jaheira
93.text: Hmm. I've learned not to unpick the legends so many have woven around our name. Seeing the hope die in a romantic's eyes - it is only funny the first few dozen times.
93.context: NodeContext: A little mock-wary about getting into the topic - people have a lot of opinions about the Harpers - but relenting, dryly amused

56.speaker: Jaheira
56.text: Some call the Harpers heroes. Others, petty meddlers who cannot help but stick their nose into every conflict they stumble across. The truth is in there somewhere.
56.context: NodeContext: Sighing, shrugging. She's unfazed by the chatter - the Harpers can be (and often are) both things

66.speaker: Jaheira
66.text: We try to work towards a common balance. If every other faction finds us equally annoying, that is probably a sign that we are succeeding.
66.context: NodeContext: Stating simply, laying down her less grand view of what they do

43.speaker: Player
43.text: You fought in the Temple of Bhaal before. Would you be able to find it again?

83.speaker: Jaheira
83.text: You speak of a battle more than a century past. Bhaal's minions led us through a maze in the Undercity, older than Baldur's Gate itself.

123.speaker: Jaheira
123.text: We paid little mind to the path ahead, let alone to how we might return. Or that we would return at all.

57.speaker: Jaheira
57.text: Still - the Undercity shifts. We might search down there - or better yet, find a Bhaalist to lead us.

115.speaker: Player
115.text: Recall what you know of Khalid.

73.text: *The quiet, unassuming shadow to Jaheira's strength, Khalid was another warrior who helped end the Bhaalspawn Crisis. Shortly after, he was murdered by the mad mage Jon Irenicus.*

40.speaker: Narrator
40.text: *The quiet, unassuming shadow to Jaheira's strength, Khalid was another warrior who helped end the Bhaalspawn Crisis. Shortly after, he was murdered by the mad mage Jon Irenicus.*

62.speaker: Player
62.text: All I'm hearing is that he was a weakling.

58.speaker: Jaheira
58.text: Then clean out your ears, and listen again.

92.speaker: Player
92.text: You seem like an odd pairing.
92.context: NodeContext: Half jokingly hinting at what first attracted her to Khalid, who on the surface is very different to her.

124.speaker: Jaheira
124.text: The druid in me would like to say it was a thing of balance. The younger woman recalls rather more about a fine bottom, and the habit not to speak unless he had something to say.
124.context: NodeContext: Half jokingly hinting at what first attracted her to Khalid, who on the surface is very different to her.

104.speaker: Player
104.text: He sounds like he had true strength.
104.context: NodeContext: Shrug - nostalgia tends to do that

34.speaker: Jaheira
34.text: Oh, I'm sure time and an ageing mind have smoothed out a few of his flaws. But he was a good man.
34.context: NodeContext: Shrug - nostalgia tends to do that

48.speaker: Jaheira
48.text: The songs make much of Khalid's meekness. The quiet little Harper who had to keep a tight hold on his courage. But he had it when it counted. And, more than that:
48.context: NodeContext: Courage is overrated - any idiot can be brave

32.speaker: Jaheira
32.text: He had compassion. When you live a Harper's life, see all that a Harper sees, that is by far the harder thing to hold on to.
32.context: NodeContext: Courage is overrated - any idiot can be brave

49.speaker: Jaheira
49.text: But a bard can tell you all the rest. As for all the things they cannot... well. I shall just have to keep those for myself.
49.context: NodeContext: Dry smile - that's all we're getting out of her.

8.speaker: Player
8.text: Tell me something about him no one else knows.

138.speaker: Jaheira
138.text: Most Harpers swagger and flash their feathers to catch your attention. Khalid was of a quieter sort.

82.speaker: Jaheira
82.text: I have never known a warrior who would go so far out of his way to avoid a fight. Which meant the few he chose were usually the right ones.

4.speaker: Jaheira
4.text: And when we were married - on an upturned cart in the rainy Dalelands - he stammered so much, I've never been sure if our vows actually counted.

37.speaker: Player
37.context: NodeContext: Cocked eyebrow, amused - we haven't upset her

3.speaker: Player
3.text: I'm sorry. I hope I didn't bring up any bad memories.
3.context: NodeContext: Cocked eyebrow, amused - we haven't upset her

26.speaker: Jaheira
26.text: Nothing that wasn't already there, fear not. But I've lived many lifetimes since Khalid died.
26.context: NodeContext: Cocked eyebrow, amused - we haven't upset her

53.speaker: Jaheira
53.text: You twine your life around the people you love. And when they are gone, you grow around their absence instead. It is just another way they shape you.
53.context: NodeContext: Shrug - she's accepted life and death, it is what it is

39.speaker: Jaheira
39.text: Which is my sage way of saying - I am in no danger of forgetting how my husband died. But I choose to remember how he lived.
39.context: NodeContext: Amused at her own trite poeticalness in the line before, as Jaheira always must be. Grand phrases or no, it is what it is.

91.speaker: Player
91.text: About that amulet I found in your house.

78.speaker: Jaheira
78.text: Oh dear - should I brace myself for some fashion advice?

20.speaker: Jaheira
20.text: But, I suppose you have earned better than glibness from me. It was a gift from my husband. Khalid.
20.context: NodeContext: Shrugging, sighing - discarding humour to actually answer our question [Kal-eed]

90.speaker: Jaheira
90.text: He was a Harper. A better one than me, truth be told - any idiot can swing a sword. But to believe in the cause, with the whole of your heart? A much trickier thing.
90.context: NodeContext: Her general tone when talking about Khalid is not grief-stricken, but fond rememberance. Even then, it's not overly emotional - she keeps those feelings and memories for herself, but has no problem picking at the wound - it's as healed as it's ever going to be.

137.speaker: Jaheira
137.text: He died. Alone, in pain, and far too young - murdered by a mage who craved immortality. I'll not grant it by naming him in the same breath as my husband.
137.context: NodeContext: Flat. No great amount of pathos, just stating facts. Hint of contempt for 'the mage' (Irenicus from BG2) in the last statement.

54.speaker: Jaheira
54.text: I think we have enough to be getting on with without the small talk - don't you?
54.context: NodeContext: Bare politeness - used when we ask her a personal question and she doesn't particularly want to answer (could range from actively disliking us to just putting us off)

17.speaker: Player
17.text: Tell me what you know about Orin.
